text:
Hi <@U01AA7U2ECA> and <@U01ABLH7DPY>!

I’m drafting some discussion questions and introduction/closing prompts for the next session. These are based on the debrief about the first session. I’ve tried to add opening and closing check-ins that will be pretty quick (one word to describe….) and I have tried to “theme” the rounds so that the questions in round 2 are bigger picture - response to the presentation and what these practices mean in the larger context of open science. Then for round 3 it focuses in on how these practices could be applied to your own research. We could also reverse these - I tend to go big picture to small more naturally, but others might prefer personal context out to big picture. Here’s what I have so far. What are your thoughts?

Introduction/Check-in: Name, Pronouns, One-word reflection that describes the most important thing people should know about you.

Round 2 questions (25 min):
·      Which project workflow practice really stood out for you? Why?
·      Were there any surprises for you in the presentation? What made them surprising?
·      In your opinion, which project workflow practices are most important for open science? Why?
·      What are some common project workflow practices that make open science more difficult?

Round 3 questions (20 min):
·      Which project workflow practices do you currently use in your research projects?
·      Which new practice could you most easily incorporate into your research? Why?
·      Which new practice would be the most difficult to incorporate into your research? Why?
·      Which new practice would be the most important to incorporate into your research right now? Why?

Closing: One-word reflection describing how you feel about project workflow and your research practice.
